title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that ABC Bank’s liabilities have increased by $40,000 and/or does not explain that Lucy’s new $40,000 cash deposit would be counted as a $40,000 increase in demand deposits on the liability side of ABC Bank’s balance sheet.

The response states that ABC Bank’s liabilities have increased by $40,000 and explains that Lucy’s new $40,000 cash deposit would be counted as a $40,000 increase in demand deposits on the liability side of ABC Bank’s balance sheet.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the dollar value of the maximum amount of new loans ABC Bank can initially make from Lucy’s deposit is $38,000 and/or does not explain that ABC Bank can lend out its excess reserves and Lucy’s deposit increased excess reserves by $38,000 ( =$40,000−$2,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai abg2da9iaacscacaaI0aGaaGimaiaacYcacaaIWaGaaGimaiaaicda cqGHsislcaGGKaGaaGOmaiaacYcacaaIWaGaaGimaiaaicdaaaa@432C@ ).

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the maximum amount by which the money supply can increase throughout the banking system as $760,000 and/or does not show the work.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that aggregate demand will increase and unemployment will decrease and/or does not explain that the increase in the money supply will result in a decrease in nominal interest rates, an increase in interest-sensitive spending, an increase in aggregate demand, an increase in real output, and a decrease in unemployment.

The response states that aggregate demand will increase and unemployment will decrease and explains that the increase in the money supply will result in a decrease in nominal interest rates, an increase in interest-sensitive spending, an increase in aggregate demand, an increase in real output, and a decrease in unemployment.
